captions.text: Give you a little drift demonstration.
(Laugh)
(Laugh)
just what should we expect from the BMW M235i?
Let's start with the name.
The 2-series essentially replaces the 1-series.

It's slightly bigger and certainly more
attractive and the M235i is the most
powerful one you can get.
But what about that M-part of its name

and the 16 badges throughout the car that
repeat it?

Never mind what they imply this isn't in
the M-car
forgetting even the special tooling M-cars normally

have this is the same as what
you get in the three and four series

though it's rated 20 horsepower higher
and it has an open differential.

Despite to confused name the M235i
though

is a simple, rear-drive, 2-door coupe with
a powerful straight six.
Can this faux M-car be a rekindling of things that made BMW great?

We achieve the fastest acceleration
without using launch control.
And at 4.4 seconds to 60 miles an hour
and 13 seconds to the quarter-mile the M235i is just
two tenths of a second behind the 1M.
Our best 60 to 0 stopping distance at 103 feet is shorter than what we recorded from the 1M
and any last generation M3. The M235

posted a 24.9 second lap around
the figure eight and
generated 0.97 G average
around the skid pad putting it off the 1M's pace
by a tenth of a second and a hundred have an average G respectively. Remember

this cars is heavier than the 1M and has less
power
than an open differential.

Verses the 1-series the two is 2.8
inches longer and 1.3 inches wider.
Its track is wider by 1.6 inches front

and 1.7 inches rear. These increases in
size make for a much better looking car.

On the 1-series the proportions never
looked quite right.
Here the two makes great use of them making it

look sporty without seeming overly
aggressive. Well-tailored describes it well.

The M235i on the road now that's an
interesting name but we'll come back to
why that's interesting in a little bit.
First let's talk about how this drives

which is probably the most important
thing about this car. Scratch that
it is the most important about this car.
This is the least expensive, smallest, fun BMW you can buy.
It's fun, it's really fun.

It has a really nice balance in the
chassis.

A lot of power, good break
performance so pretty much
everywhere throughout the road it's nicely controlled
and it seems really fast too.
It has a pretty stout amount of grip thanks to
these Michelin pilot super sport tires. They do need some heat in them
as we found at the test track but after driving on them a bit they

feel great you can carry some pretty
good speed in them.
Overall the whole package feels really nice there's pieces that
help with that. The transmission is 8-speed automatic.
It is very good, better than a lot of
twin clutch transmissions out there.

When I go hard on the brakes it actually
downshifts into high RPM's

anticipating your need to accelerate
hard out.

Tight ratio space is really nice because this
engine

has a lot of power. A really healthy
mid-range about
3500 rpm and on it's really
meaty punch this engine has and it feels really

good to keep the engine right there. That
said you can let the engine scream

all the way to its 7000 RPM redline and
it feels just as fun too
if not a little more because that's where the horsepower peak is.
Speaking of 320 horse

claim, but I wouldn't be surprised if
this was making that power at the rear
tires.
This car feels very, very powerful

and its sounds really good to you get
that straight
6 howl.
And with the windows down when cruising you can faintly hear the turbo charger.
Now the parts that are confusing about the M235i
Well it has an M-badge in front of the name
in fact it has something like seventeen M-badges on the exterior of the car.

It's very proudly displaying the M-name
which is interesting because it's not
an M car.
You can get the optional diff, the optional sports suspension and braking upgrade.
But if the car is an M235i
why aren't those parts standard?
If you're going to use the M-name
make it have M-components. So it's kinda confusing a little bit frustrating

but it's also meaningless because this
is just a good handling car.
Now let's give it to Randy Pobst.
Nice little drift.
Good mid range torque from a 3 liter turbo charged 6.
That has in my opinion better top end than it used to.
It pulls all the way to 7 it used to dive to about 6,000 rpm
and you know what? 0 turbo lag.
The engine feels more like a naturally aspirated 5-liter than a turbocharged
3-liter.
It's a sweetheart of an engine.
Pretty strong engine noise.
That's not exactly what I'm used to in a BMW 6 but I think I like it.
Right to the edge.
Feel those soft shocks see all the movement in the car.
Probably rides rather well on the street.
Good steering response big fat wheel in my hand.
On power all four wheels are working.
The 2-series is balanced
it's a dance partner
it follows my lead. I'm liking it
a lot.
Its got enough M in it to make it work here
at Willow Springs.
And now introducing the Ignition Hot Lap.
You might be hesitant about
the M235i because of its name and open diff

but spend time behind the wheel
experience
its blend of power, balance, and grip and you'll turn into a fan.
The M235i is one of the best driving BMWs
since the last generation M3 and 1M. It's on par with those cars

not only on performance standards but
most importantly
in also how much it makes you smile.
By the way Rodney knows how fast we were going back there
that was like 100. (OS) You've been going about 100.
Thank you, BMW welcome back!

title: 2014 BMW M235i: More Than Just The Bargain M? - Ignition Ep. 106

comments.text:
All this guy ever says is, "...it's really nice."  You'd think someone who 
drives a zillion different cars could give a more concrete comparison and 
make statements with actual meaning.﻿
comments.author: mephisto212

comments.text:
After i could testdrive the m235i i'll always prefer the 1m Coupè over the 
m235i.
The 1m is a real M-car, the first thing you'll notice when you hop from 
m235 into an 1m is the difference in precision of the steering, the 
violence how the Power kicks in and the perfect balance. It just dosen't 
come with all the cool extras you can equip in the m235i and it consumes 
more Fuel. Personally i think it looks way more aggresive than the m235i.
It's Pure M.﻿
comments.author: Electrojudaz

comments.text: 6.47 it looks like that drift set the road/camera on fire lol!﻿
comments.author: Chris Dorgan

comments.text: Reminds me of the e30 m3.﻿

comments.text:
LSD should come standard on any car with a M badge on it, I think BMW 
should also re-evaluate their exhaust systems on these 6-cyl motors. They 
don't sound all that great.﻿

Subaru STI .......  1.26.20 ..... 35k $.... AWD
M235i ................. 1.26.37 ..... 44k $ .... RWD

hmmmmmm.................... I think I'll take a wingless sti and just call

that is worth an extra 12k$ over the sti, but from a purely performance 
point of view, the bimmer is not worth 12k$ more than the sti, actually

bad car lol!....it's an awesome car! ! Different cars for different 
budgets, I'm happy both cars exist, more choice is always better for the 
consumer

it to be at least decent, and the ride quality of the bmw is far better 
then the sti u feel like ur driving a tank and yes i understand its made 
for doing all kinds of rally shit and thats why its made that way but lets 
be honest who uses it for that besides a street car

just saying and thats for the xdrive 235i

comments.text:
+Evarn evon if a Ford is your cup of tea well then so be it... expectations 
are high on this new hothatch, the performance appears to be there but 
reliability remains the unknown, it is comforting to know that it is built 
in Germany however (!) >=p
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text:
The RS isn't out yet, and I'm guessing it will cost around the same as an 
sti, or probably more due to the better performance. This is the first good 
RS that will be avaliable in the U.S. It has a tuned ecoboost engine that 
is confirmed to have more than 320 hp. No one has found the true tuning 
potential for it yet, and it could be crazy! The ecoboost mustang has some 
tunes that give it crazy amounts of tourque, and the RS engine will only 
have more potential. Anyways, I'm not planning on putting tons of mods on 
it and making a 600 hp beast. maybe something small but I want it as a 
peppy and reliable daily while I save for my next car.
comments.author: Evarn evon

comments.text:
+Evarn evon I can add 3000$ worth of parts to an sti and blow your $$$RS$$$ 
out of the water, see, it never ends...
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text:
The m235i has class, and the subaru is just dull and childish. I'm waiting 
to get the 2016 RS, which will blow both tese cars out the water.
comments.author: Evarn evon

comments.text:
This car makes only sense if youre driving at race track. In everyday 
driving you can only use 5% of its capabilities. ﻿
comments.author: Nyana11

comments.text:
+Cade Nguyen yeah sure, this "touch of sportiness" will cost you at the end 
your driving license.
comments.author: Nyana11

comments.text:
+Nyana11 Not true....it's not really a track ready car, it's more of a 
daily driver with a touch of sportiness.
comments.author: Cade Nguyen

comments.text:
I don't know why car lovers love subaru. I have driven like a forester(i 
can't remember the name accurately)or a legacy, but it feels like normal 
saloon. There was no fun. Too much understeer and it felt like they had not 
even tried to deal with it. Totally disappointed. Yeah, i know that STI is 
different. (I haven't driven brand new STI, but i have driven older one. It 
was disappointing experience as well.) I know that Subaru had won at WRC. 
(As i remember, they had won only once.) But you know, compared to BMW, 
it's like.. i don't know what to say, it's just a typical tuned 4 door 
saloon. On a paper, it's really great car, but, in the real world, is it? ﻿
comments.author: 박휘수

comments.text:
With STI you can change settings to make most power go to rear wheels, it 
acts like a rear wheel drive, you can blow donuts in the snow and have a 
blast on dirt roads.
comments.author: semiautoriflelover1

comments.text:
Well, It's not just about BMW vs Subaru. it was about feeling what you can 
experience in the car, and differences between AWD and RWD. I wish some of 
whom understand what i want to tell.
comments.author: 박휘수

comments.text:
I'm not saying that AWD is shitty thing compared to real wheel drive. It's 
much faster and, much safer than real wheel drive.I live in Seoul, it snows 
not much as NY but still, snows a lot. So I prefer AWD much more than real 
wheel drive in daily driving. but not in sport driving. it hasn't something 
that i can feel in real wheel drive car.(These days, this 'something' in 
real wheel drive car is getting weaker. sad thing.)
comments.author: 박휘수

comments.text:
Come to NY during winter and you will see why we love AWD...love my 2015 
Subaru WRX
comments.author: semiautoriflelover1

comments.text:
judging from the lap times in the video above, yeah the sti is pretty good 
since it beats the M235i lol
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text: Did America not get an M135i?﻿
comments.author: DangeRoss

comments.text: +DangeRoss it was called 135is
comments.author: Jacob Palmer

comments.text:
Funny how C&D got 0-60: 4.3 sec in the 3565 lb 235i. Yet a 3373 lb 320hp 
(same as M235), 135is did 4.8 sec to 60 mph. Absolutely bs. The M235 does 
0-30: 1.8 sec. Rolling 5-60 mph: 5.1 sec. If you do some math, you'll see 
that 0-5 mph takes .3 tenths, so that M235's 0-60 is around 4.8, not 4.3 or 
4.4 sec. 20hp and 17 tq is not going to cut/drop 0-60 times 3/4 of a sec. 
Never. I'm seeing lots of problems with the 8 spd too. Why can't just one 
Manu stick with what is proven and works instead of trying to best everyone 
else with firsts. Nobody cars about firsts. Please. 7 spd DCT needs to come 
back, steering feel needs to come back. It's sad that BMW's in general, 
have become very disconnected to the road and driving experience which is 
what earned them the "Ultimate Driving Machine" monkier. These days it's 
the "Ultimate Computer controlled Machine" video game manufacturer. BMW 
your losing tens of thousands of faithful clients every month. That would 
other me. ﻿
comments.author: 08turboSS

comments.text: Technology:
comments.author: promodelred

comments.text:
I have the M235i in manual which is fantastic, but I also drove it with the 
8 speed ZF and it was fantastic too! The only reason I have the manual is 
because that's what the dealer had and it was very difficult to find these 
cars last April without a custom order and a long wait!  I installed the 
Black kidney grill, M LSD, MPExhaust, M Electronic steering with shifter 
and handbrake! The car is just perfect in this configuration and in my 
opinion is the best BMW in the lineup M or no M included. Go test drive one 
for your self and you will know what I mean. Its a very special car and I 
think many people are overlooking it or just being haters about it.  Yes I 
also drove the new Subaru STI and its no where near the quality, power 
delivery and class of this BMW, but  I respect other people opinion about 
it. I think many of us who own the M235i can afford way more expensive cars 
but chose the 2 series because its just a heck of a fun car to drive and 
that is what I care about and yes its nice to save some money.  One last 
thing, there is nothing confusing about its name and I can care less. Good 
luck finding one to test drive!﻿
comments.author: skrads

comments.text:
+skrads What's it like with the LSD? My biggest gripe with the M235i was 
how much body roll there was, I wish it was better dampened. If it was me, 
I would get the KW Coilovers with DDC (electronic dampening), plug and play 
into the BMW system.
comments.author: Cade Nguyen

comments.text:
To Chris Dorgan, send me your email and I can show you pictures of how my 
MPerformance exhaust looks without the diffuser setup. Yes I still enjoy my 
M235i everyday and I like driving it on sport setting with only chassis 
setting turned to sport setting. I like the sound better in comfort mode. 
By the way, for serious driving on the track, I just press the traction 
button and hold it for a few seconds. What this does is turns off traction 
control, dynamic stability control, let's LSD be fully active, sets the M 
exhausts to its loudest position and keeps the pedal response in comfort 
mode for better control. Sort of like an M button.
comments.author: skrads

comments.text:
The M Performance exhaust is worth it. In comfort mode you can hear it best 
when you have the windows down and sunroof open. In sports + mode it gets 
louder. No drone either setting, but I prefer it in comfort mode because it 
sounds like a classic in-line six BMW from the past!
comments.author: skrads

comments.text:
+skrads agreed man, I got the ZF auto because I do a lot of town driving 
and quite frankly couldn't be arsed in traffic with manual anymore. I got 
the M Performance Body Kit but didn't get the LSD :( got the suspension 
though. The dealer didn't tell me I needed to change the exhaust for it to 
fit properly so the standard exhaust sits underneath the M performance body 
kit instead of flush or even sticking out a bit lol. Gutted, currently 
trying to sort it out with BMW. It was how the car drove that sold me man, 
I went for a test drive, had a 370z, never even thought of selling it as 
only had it two years and then after driving that BM my mind was changed 
there n then. Great car, practical, fast, stealth when it needs to be, bit 
rude when it needs to be lol! The only thing I would change is the 
dealerships competence lol! People can bitch and moan about price and 
better bang for your bucks etc but tbh I want to be sitting in something 
nice, not something full of hard plastic and leather that makes your arse 
sweat haha.You pay for quality, the engine is smooth as silk, it's easy to 
drive when you need it to be but is lively when your out on a country road. 
It's preference man, people have an idea of what they want and opinions 
from vids like these but until you've test driven a few things and sat in 
them and touched them you don't have a clue what they're like. Hope you;re 
still enjoying yours man! I put some pics of mine on the car throttle 
website btw if you wanna check it out :P
comments.author: Chris Dorgan

comments.text:
+skrads I wish I could listen to the m performance exhaust inside the car. 
I felt the standard exhaust was a bit too quiet for me.
comments.author: Cade Nguyen

comments.text:
They sell Racechips on Amazon and ebay. Racechip is a German company that 
is legit. I don't know much more than what you can gather googling like a 
madman "which I did". There are a few forums and very little real 
information is ever presented by the forum members imo. I took the chance 
because I didn't want another jb4. I was worried the dealer would discover 
the JB4 and the Racechip is almost effortless to remove; for me.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text: +C Straley i found the info http://www.racechip.com/chiptuning-what-is-it/
comments.author: skrads

comments.text: +C Straley can you give me more info about this chip? Thanks
comments.author: skrads

comments.text:
+skrads The Race Chip is a great addition too btw. It took me 10 minutes to 
install it and the results on the stock settings made me pretty damn happy. 
I actually improved my mpg by 1.5 mpg. Not much but still I didn't expect 
it. I am averaging 21 mpg and I hammer it quite often.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text: Shouldn't the price of BMWs come down with the falling euro?﻿
comments.author: Daniel Feldman

comments.text: +Daniel Feldman no
comments.author: Jacob Palmer

comments.text: If it's not an m car, then why the hell does it have an m badge?﻿

comments.text:
Agreed...the faux "m" badge is stupid but w/e...Will get the M2 when it 
comes out.

comments.text:
It's an M Performance car. Competition to Audi's S models, it's not rocket 
science.
comments.author: Tuddec

comments.text:
Why does everybody have a problem with the name. Sure it's only for 
marketing purpouse but audi does the same thing for years with it's "S" 
brand. ﻿
comments.author: RacingRalphEVO

comments.text:
6 cylinders, and a turbo and only 320 horsepower? cmon... the sti has over 
300 with 2 less cylinders, the evo with a full litre less displacement is 
still close behind.﻿
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text: +Jakub Buchowiecki Yeah but i'm just talking about engine vs engine
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text: +mkelebay and then you remember the drive train loss through the 4wd/awd
comments.author: Jakub Buchowiecki

comments.text: +Jesse Pena Fahrvergnügen
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text:
Another way to look at is all BMW's regardless of model, have good looking 
front ends...?

People often confuse my M235i for an M4 for a just second. I see it in 
their eyes and of course disappointment probably follows when they notice 
they weren't ogling the M4. This annoys me and gets back to your point. BMW 
really needs to stop following this protocol of everything "looks the 
same". Except for varying sizes and doors they look too much alike.imo

The i8 is a departure and it looks damn nice but it's price puts it in 
unobtanium land for me. It sure would be nice to see some distinct design 
in various models that immediately catch the eyes and people know what it 
is because it's a variation on the boring theme. The M2 may do that and I 
am waiting impatiently for news.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text:
Every BMW looks the same in front, I would feel bad for a guy buying an M3 
and the base models all have the same front grill. It's time to add some 
new styling.
comments.author: semiautoriflelover1

comments.text:
+mkelebay If you think that dollar for dollar performance is all you get 
then go buy a mustang GT. The arguments you make about the the M235i will 
not apply to the Mustang. You are paying for engineering with the BMW not 
just track times you realize this no?
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text: They make an xDrive version with AWD
comments.author: promodelred

comments.text:
I live in NY and it snows all the damn time here! The all wheel drive of my 
2015 WRX was just amazing in the snow, I had the fastest car all winter, 
you can do full throttle launches and the car didn't move off the road. 
This BMW is really nice but not good for NY. Perfect car for California 
Hipsters.
comments.author: semiautoriflelover1

comments.text:
+promodelred Go watch the end of this video, its beat by a mustang, and a 
subaru, shit even the subaru wrx which is a 26k car is only a second 
slower, and honestly if 0-60 is all that matters why buy a car that has a 
sport tuned suspension, just buy a muscle car and throw sticky tires on. 
Motor trend tested both cars and the subaru was faster, a mustang was 
faster.
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text:
Alright, I wasn't even in this but now you're starting to get aggravating. 
I'm sorry that you're just pissed off because the STIs have gotten slower 
over the years and you're probably pissed off from riding around in the 
plastic rattle trap all day, I don't blame you I really don't. Anyways, 
before you go talking your shit about the M235i, go check out the 0-60 in 
4.3 from car and driver and see what they ran in the new STI (which is 
rated at 4.9 I think?) Also, there is a race between a manual and RWD m235i 
(slowest available version of the car, not even the 8-speed or AWD) vs a 
2015 STI on YouTube from professional car races and the M literally dusts 
it. Not even close. I still love the subby and would buy one but it's just 
no M235i on top end and anything out of first gear :P
comments.author: promodelred

comments.text:
+C Straley It's not about what the best bmw has to offer, you have a car 
that is built on performance first yes? and that car is beat by a car that 
costs 10k less, and has a design that is nearly a decade old. Pobst is good 
at driving all vehicles fast, he drove a mclaren and a 918 at nearly the 
same speed, so i think he can handle a wee little sti and an 2 series. At 
the end of the day, its a garbage value car.
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text:
+mkelebay Accelerating hard at 60 everyday merging on the highway but never 
in town. I got Xdrive and the auto.so I can maximize 0-60 in my M235i. Not 
sure if that would make any difference on Pobst's times at willow springs. 
I can say that Pobst is very good at driving awd vehicles fast. The M235i 
isn't a supercar or even near the best BMW has to offer so don't get too 
excited about the STI results.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text:
+C Straley How many times are you still accelerating hard at 60 mph? Sorry 
but the old ass design of the subaru, which is outdated as HELL compared to 
most cars still is at the same place as the m235i, from motortrend "On the 
1.6-mile Streets of Willow race course with racer Randy Pobst behind the 
wheel, for instance, only 0.25 second separated fastest from slowest. "
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text:
+mkelebay You do realize the M235i will eat the STI's lunch stock...? The 
EVO is a joke. The M235i with awd and the 8 speed auto with launch control 
would smoke an STI. The RWD M235i would catch the STI at between 50-60mph 
(traction) and walk away. Lets not even talk about mods because they are 
both major moddable but most people wont unless it's fairly easy. I think 
stock hp is much closer to 350hp on the M235i; imo. I agree with your 
statement on HP though. Why not tell everyone it's 350? I think this car 
would steal MANY more M3,M4 buyers if the M235i was marketed at 350hp;imo. 
The new M2 will probably be 400hp which is enough to bring me onboard, as 
long as it doesn't become a different animal
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text:
+mkelebay​ I've owned a 370z too, and test driven audi and mercedes and 
they don't drive half as good as bmw. I know it sounds overkill or like I'm 
on their nuts but you have to drive them to truly understand. I didn't till 
I bought my first one 5 years ago. The technology is always ahead of the 
competition and I compare it to a pc vs a macbook pro. It's not even close 
on technology and convenience. I understand not everyone cares about it, I 
at one point didn't care about it, but once you have it you definitely 
don't want to lose it. One day you'll bit the bullet and buy one and then 
you'll see why people still buy a bmw even though there's cars that seem 
comparable or better on paper.
comments.author: Jesse Pena

comments.text:
+Jesse Pena I can agree with you subaru has a cheap interior, perhaps 
improving now, but in the past most definitely, but you can't call them 
unreliable, those cars are built like fuckin tanks, and have proven it on 
thousands and thousands of cars. Other options for cars audi s4 if you want 
some BS prestige, scat pack challenger or the charger, as well as the 
mustang and camaro, or the 370 even, most of those cars are all 5-10k 
cheaper than the bmw, and would beat it on a track or drag strip.
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text:
+mkelebay​Yeah well I just sold wrx, the car felt from the inside no better 
than a paper plate. The door panel arm support plastic was cracking, dash 
rattled like a rattle snake even on smooth new roads and on pot holes it 
felt like car was going to split in half. I bought that 2014 wrx with only 
5 miles and after 10k miles it felt like a bmw with 90k miles. This is not 
an exaggeration, ove owned 3 bmw's drove them new and used and even the one 
that I ran up the most miles at 80k it still felt new and smelled new. The 
wrx sometimes smelled like a dump and I cleaned my car 3x's a week. I sold 
it after 20k miles I couldn't take it anymore and bought a fully loaded 
435i. Now I finally feel like I'm back in a real solid car again that 
doesn't feel like a one time use party paper plate.
comments.author: Jesse Pena

comments.text:
+Jesse Pena I dunno say what you want, for a RWD car that makes 320 
horsepower, and STARTING cost of 44k, there are a lot of options that would 
quite frankly demollish it.
comments.author: mkelebay

comments.text:
+mkelebay 320 is underrated from BMW, that's more like 320WHP, the sti 
mostly likely has 270WHP. That's about 50WHP difference and about 80BHP 
difference.
comments.author: Jesse Pena

comments.text:
+Robert C sti shitty AWD? lol. centre diff with LSDs front and rear.... 
M235i NO fkng LSD anywhere! LOL
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text:
Can anyone tell me the name of the yellow sports car at :20 seconds in? 
Much appreciated!﻿
comments.author: Sullivan Prod.

comments.text: McLaren P1
comments.author: Bob Jones

comments.text: Nice review and beard:)﻿
comments.author: northfulton92

comments.text:
Can someone please explain why people are saying this car is 
overpriced/bad? It's worth somewhere between 46-50 grand which is cheaper 
then the 335i, but gives better performance numbers in every test. Am I 
missing something here? It's not even a true "M" car and yet still 
delivers.﻿
comments.author: Brian Huang

comments.text:
+DANNY40379 Do you think that the same quality of materials and components 
are used in BMW's and Subaru's? It's not just the interiors.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text: +TassieLorenzo YES it's a BMW not an econo Subaru.
comments.author: C Straley

comments.text:
+DANNY40379 No an STI doesn't come close in power, refinement, sound 
isolation, interior quality, etc.
comments.author: Joseph C.

comments.text:
+TassieLorenzo actually the interiors are not comparable, I see the bimmer 
maybe 6k-8k more expensive but not 15k$, the extra dough is for the BMW 
badge only
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text:
+TassieLorenzo It's not "because it's a BMW." Have you driven an STI and a 
BMW 135i or 335i? Build quality, power, rattles, interior, noise isolation, 
etc. don't come close.
comments.author: Joseph C.

comments.text:
But isn't that how all luxury brands are? BMW, Mercedes Benz, Audi, they 
are all going to be priced higher then brands like Subaru's or Volkswagen, 
even if the performance numbers are the same. When people buy these cars, 
it's not just the performance. It's the title, the quality, and the 
technology. Sad, but true.
comments.author: Brian Huang

comments.text:
Why can't it be priced closer to the WRX STi?  Why does it have to be $15k 
more expensive just "because it's a BMW"!?
comments.author: TassieLorenzo

comments.text:
I have finally leased: the 228i with track package. I have this car for 3 
months. Every day I drive it, I go into a conversation with myself ( just a 
bit OCD.. Lou have previously driven the m235 and base 228. The car I have 
THEORETICALLY makes the 228 ride and handle like the 235. 
My car is an indignant to me! I have concluded that my car ( hence, the 
235, is most and foremost totally enjoyable in only 2 situations: on open 
highways and a race track, the latter of which I've never been on. In my 
car, the comfort mode barely gets by on city or suburban town, everyday 
roads. The steering tightens up splendidly in sport mode, but the 
suspension is less enjoyable and a bit jittery much of the time. I realize 
NOW, that this track handling suspension, on balance is to firm for me and 
less "gliding or supple" on regular roads. I try to remember my test of the 
base 228; I found it made me want to make the plunge for this car... Mind 
you, i wnt to feel the road and have tight hefty steering, but my track 
package (suspension or large tires) is a bit too much! I lower tire peas 
urge a bit and feel a bit better on city or town driving. Nonetheless , the 
base 228 might have been a better choice. Needless to say, all reviewers 
love the m235 suspension in all areas of driving road conditions. I guess I 
need a TOUCH less road feel or a touch more absorption of road cracks and 
nooks for everyday driving. 
In the other hand, the car accelerates wonderfully and is still fun to 
drive in the BMW tradition. On the other hand..... Maybe I am a Mercedes 
(sport suspension) man at heart!!!
WTF... The new c class will be thought of in near future with its varying 
options. By the way, a brief drive of the latest 3 series gave me the 
suspension and steering I need: but the extra 2 doors I don't!
﻿
comments.author: ClassicPerformances2

comments.text:
+ClassicPerformances2 Go look at Bilstein suspension and have them valve 
the shocks for comfort. If budget permits look at Bilstein coilovers. 
Monotube shocks are the best shock design by a country mile.
comments.author: Lachee Brun

comments.text:
these cars are marketed as a driver's car.  Not sure why anyone would want 
this for city/suburban driving.  Go to the track... maybe you'll feel 
better about your purchase.

comments.author: wonderwall135

comments.text:
I'm not sure what Carlos is talking about. You can get the limited-slip 
diff as an option, but not a brake upgrade or a sport suspension option, at 
least not here in the USA at this time-11/30/14. I don't think you'd need a 
suspension upgrade because the M235i already has the Adaptive M Suspension 
standard. Bigger brakes are always nice, though.

Keep in mind that the M235i isn't cheap. I priced one out on the BMW web 
site with options that most everyone would want and it was just over 
$51,000. I don't know what you could buy that would give you equal, or 
better, performance for that money, though. About all I can think of is the 
new Mustang GT. Any other ideas folks?﻿
comments.author: Jeff Puha

comments.text: +DANNY40379 True. I'd love to have a Porsche Cayman/Boxter as a second car.
comments.author: MD4ProductionsMD4

comments.text: +MD4ProductionsMD4 2nd car?

comments.text: +DANNY40379 The boxer/cayman don't have a back seat
comments.author: MD4ProductionsMD4

comments.text:
once you hit $51k the boxster/cayman come into play and then suddenly 
everything becomes clear...=)
comments.author: DANNY40379

comments.text:
+Jeff Puha Yes, the Audi TTS would be pretty comparable as in 
specifications.I think  the Audi TTS is more expensive though ($60 000, at 
least where I live) which I think would be more comparable to the BMW Z4 
and the Mercedes SLK. The Mustang GT would probably come the closest in 
acceleration and power. Where the Mustang isn't comparable is in build 
quality and interior design. I totally agree with you, the M235i is a 
definite winner!
comments.author: MD4ProductionsMD4

comments.text:
+MD4ProductionsMD4 I was thinking some more about competitors for the 
M235i, and I think the Audi TTS might be a better one than the S3. It's a 
coupe and, evidently, has sharper handling than the S3. It only has 265-hp, 
but it weighs less than the M235i. I still think the M235i beats it in 
acceleration, though. The pricing is almost identical to the M235i. Once 
again, no manual available.:(
comments.author: Jeff Puha

comments.text:
+MD4ProductionsMD4 Yes. I think the Audi S3 would be pretty close, perhaps 
just a bit slower to 60. Good pick. The deal-breaker for me concerning the 
Audi is that you can't get it with a manual gearbox, which is odd because 
you can get the larger S5 with one. I really like that car-its interior as 
well.
The Cayman is too expensive to be considered a rival, in my opinion. It's 
quite a different kind of car as well, and doesn't have the practicality or 
utility of the others.
I still think the Mustang GT is one of the only comparably priced cars that 
has equal, or better, acceleration and handling than the M235i. You don't 
the same interior material quality, though.
The  M235i is a definite winner. Thanks for your ideas.
comments.author: Jeff Puha

comments.text:
The new Audi S3 maybe? It isn't as fast or as sporty as the BMW although it 
is another option. Also the Porsche Cayman is comparable although about 
$10,000 more expensive! The M235i is probably the best sports car you can 
buy for around that price tag, at least in my opinion.

comments.author: Mbt Summerland

comments.text:
Although this isn't an M car the proportions and grip are phenomenal, plus 
this is almost a rekindling of what made the BMW name small,light, and 
nimble. Although many think its too understated thats the way BMW has 
always been. A bit conservative on the styling but while still adding 
components of performance for the track or just for fun on the road. If you 
want to complain about horsepower tune the M235i, give it an exhaust, give 
it a limited slip differential and get rid of some weight and surely then 
you would have a true M235i for those who can not wait on the 370+ hp M2﻿

comments.text:
paddles are fine for racing but you still need a clutch to drive it on its 
limit

however over steering with paddles sucks if your planning to drift you need

comments.author: MustardTiger

comments.text:
+MustardTiger i'm also not sure whether it downshifts when you break if 
you're utilizing the paddles. Probably only when you're in regular drive 
mode. I don't know forsure though!
comments.author: Dan R

comments.text:
Flappy paddles and the new BMW dual clutch transmissions give the driver a 
ton of control. Manual elitists's will shirk the notion that a car without 
a third pedal can be engaging to drive, but it's 2014 and flappy paddle 
gearboxes are pretty incredible these days (if you have the right car). 
Just look at the GT-R and 911. People think they're members of an elite 
club just because they know how a clutch works and can heel and toe. Of 
course it's OK that we still love manual transmissions, but the notion that 
an automatic cannot be as engaging to drive is false in my mind.
comments.author: Dan R

comments.text:
I haven't used this gearbox no but the fact it downshifts when you brake 
doesn't replace manual gears.

if you want to be able to drift and / or race you NEED to have full control 
over your gear box utilizing the cars torque band and grab from the engine 
as you let the clutch out for example while braking heavily for the next 
turn or gripping u the back tires when u have just abit to much momentum in 
a slide  

theirs a good reason you don't see drift /race cars in auto....
comments.author: MustardTiger

comments.text:
auto tragic gearbox? I don't believe you've used this particular 
gearbox. no reason why the better engineering solution cannot also be the 
most fun. Plus, dual clutch will always be faster, better gearing and shift 
time and all.
comments.author: Dan R

comments.text:
manual hands down

no better way to ruin a balanced fun chassis/power combination than with an 
auto tragic gearbox
